abstracts.cdata!:
The Henan Towns Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project for China was deemed to have an
            unsatisfactory outcome, with moderately unsatisfactory
            performances by the Bank as well as the borrower. The
            project implementation was unsatisfactory due to
            difficulties with procurement, weakness in project
            management, ineffective use of technical assistance and slow
            response to management issues. Of the three project
            development outcome indicators, two were partially achieved,
            while the third was unsatisfactory. Significant lessons
            learned during the implementation of the project include: 1)
            hiring of consultants to help the borrower in project
            preparation must start at project identification stage; 2) a
            full understanding of the screening and selection criteria
            by participating counties is important to ensure success; 3)
            engagement of both a team of experts and a design institute
            working in tandem to support the Project Management Offices
            (PMOs) and Water Utility Companies (WUCs) in preparation of
            a FSR (Financial Stability Report) is not practical; and 4)
            programmatic loan with a framework for selecting and
            appraising subprojects could have been more appropriated.
